User attempting to visit a suspicious we.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek fileinfo.log; Windows Event ID 4688
User attempting to visit a suspicious we.Action: Monitor Zeek http.log for connections to newly registered domains or known malicious URLs. Monitor Zeek fileinfo.log for file downloads, especially executables or documents from untrusted sources. Correlate suspicious network activity with user activity logs (e.g., Windows Event ID 4688 on endpoints) to identify processes like web browsers or downloaders active around the time of the suspicious network events. Use time series analysis to identify bursts of suspicious activity by a specific user.

Increased external network activity targ.Action: Analyze Zeek dns.log for unusual external DNS queries originating from internal hosts targeting services or domains not typically accessed. Examine Zeek conn.log for low-and-slow scanning or probing activity towards internal ranges from external sources, potentially using information gathered via voice calls. Use correlation analysis to link suspicious DNS/network probes to specific user activity if possible.

User successfully authenticates to exter.Action: Correlate successful external remote service logon events (Windows Event ID 4624 Logon Type 3/10, Zeek conn.log to external services) with reported times of suspicious phone calls or user reports. Identify users who successfully log in from new/unusual geographic locations or devices shortly after such calls. Use time series analysis to look for deviations from a user's standard remote access login patterns or a sudden shift in typical behavior based on frequency.

Connection from a user's host to an exte.Data: Zeek conn.log; Zeek http.log; Zeek ssl.log
Connection from a user's host to an exte.Action: Monitor Zeek logs (conn.log, http.log, ssl.log) for connections originating from internal user hosts to external IPs/domains that match known callback phishing infrastructure, newly registered domains, or threat intelligence feeds associated with credential harvesting sites. Correlate these connections with user reports of suspicious phone calls. Use frequency analysis to identify users or hosts with a high number of connections to suspicious external destinations.
